name: Thimble Creek
description:
Introduction

A nice open creek with lots of swept bedrock. The descent is pretty action-packed without much walking between rappels. There are at least two options:

  • Lower Thimble: Park at the bottom and bushwhack your way up to the hanging valley. Requires some route-finding. This is about a half-day outing.
  • Full Thimble: Requires a shuttle car up to Blue Lake and hike in. Expect this outing to take most of the day.

Approach

Lower Thimble

From the Lewis River Horse Camp, follow FR 93 northward for 5.8mi to a T-jct. Turn right on FR 9341 for 0.2mi. You will pass the top of Thimble Creek (good checkpoint). Continue ahead maybe 100ft to find a nice big campsite on the right with room for several vehicles.

If you don't have a shuttle, return to Thimble Creek and locate a campsite on the north side of the road (not as much parking). Thrash your way up the north side of the creek and bear over into the hanging valley to begin the first drop at ~3,800 feet. The walk is through a beautiful forest, although the bushwhacking is thick in places. Closer to the creek may be better / less steep terrain (?). Expect the approach to take at least an hour even for experienced off-trail hikers.

Upper Thimble

Return to the T-jct and head south (straight) on FR 93. Continue for ~6mi before taking a sharp right turn onto FR 9331. Follow the main road upwards for ~3mi to locate the unsigned Blue Lake Trailhead. This road has several large berms. High clearance probably a good idea or a 2WD you don't love too much. The shuttle takes about 25min one-way.

At the Blue Lake trailhead, locate the unsigned trail heading off north into the forest. It's obvious when you see it. Follow the trail for approx. 1.25mi, looping around the north side of Blue Lake and gradually ascending slopes beyond. At around 4700ft, just past a large cut log that the trail passes through, break off and bushwhack 0.1mi east/northeast to find a good place to drop into Upper Thimble. Bushwhack time = 5min. Off-trail travel is easy.

Descent

Watch your footing in Thimble as it can be quite slippery.

Upper Thimble

In late summer Upper Thimble will have relatively low water.

  • R1: 20ft. Rappel or downclimb.

Reach the top of Upper Thimble Falls which is ~350ft high. This must be rappelled in two stages (R2 & R3).

  • R2: Run the rope out a full 200ft from a big tree DCL atop the falls. The fall drops through several tiers into a large sloping rock bowl. Landing is a marginally flat area not far above the R3 drop. Be careful moving around here as the creek is slippery and going for a tumble would be deadly.

DANGER - A sketchy traverse is currently required to get up to the R3 anchor, which is another big tree DCL above the next drop. Getting to the anchor is very difficult to protect. It would be much better if another rappel station could be established somewhere in the bowl or one of the tiers above. A quality bolt station would make the next stage a lot safer. Options for natural anchors here are extremely limited.

  • R3: 120ft. Rappelling from the tree is pretty dirty and loose. Beware knocking rocks down on yourself and people below. (Rappelling from this tree would be unnecessary if the anchor situation at the bottom of R2 could be improved.)
  • R4: 125ft not quite vertical. Anchored on a tree DCL.

Short drop: 15ft. Downclimb DCR or rappel.

  • R5: 60ft. Anchored on a log DCR. Bottom of this rappel is choked with debris - e.g. fallen trees and rocks that have fallen in. Easily bypassed DCR.
  • R6: 150ft in several tiers. Anchored on a log in middle. Descend a long chute which had a bunch of debris in 2019.

At the bottom the creek flattens out and the terrain opens up. Continue downstream to a short 6ft drop. Downclimb DCR.

Below this last step, you've reached the hanging valley between sections of the creek. Either stay in the creek and follow it down, or cut out DCL and follow animal trails along the northern bank to the top of the lower section. Distance is around 0.2mi and should take about 10min. Easy off-trail.

Lower Thimble

Somewhere in the valley the tributary enters from Blue Lake and the the flow will double, if not more. The lower section of the creek has 6-8 rappels and none bigger than 200 feet.

Beginning the descent around 3800' elevation, expect a minor downclimb or two before things get rolling.

  • R7: 10ft drop followed by a short slide (15ft). The vertical drop should be rappelled, but the slide can be downclimbed DCR.
  • R8: 30ft falls, followed by short horizontal section, then a second tier of perhaps 25ft. The second tier is very slippery/blocky, but can be downclimbed carefully.
  • R9: 80ft. Fun rappel.
  • R10: 50ft slide.

Below R10 are several downclimbs. Bypass a big fallen tree DCR.

  • R11: 175ft low-angle slide in several tiers. Could also be done in a couple rappels if concerned about rope pull.

Climb down an easy ramp to reach a logjam barricading the creek. It proved possible to downclimb around it DCR. This is right above R12.

  • R12: 20ft off a tree DCL. (Use caution approaching the tree as it may be slippery; may be better to anchor back on the logjam.)
  • R13: Lower Thimble Falls. The tallest vertical rappel on lower Thimble Creek at perhaps 150ft broken up into two tiers. The first tier of 50ft into a hanging pool, then 85ft into a shallow pool at the base of the falls. Sweet rappel.

Continue downstream ~5min to the road. There are a couple minor drops that might be downclimbed or rappelled.

  • R14: 8ft. Short rappel into a pool. Brushy bypass possible DCL.

On reaching the culvert, exit up to the road.

Exit

At the culvert, scramble up the bank to the road. Turn left and walk 1min back to your car.

Extra Bonus Rappel

If you're not beat and have a little extra energy, go through the culvert. A few hundred feet downstream, reach a large bedrock waterslide.

  • R15: 100ft low-angle ramp. Might be downclimbable, but don't slip. Ramp culminates in a short steep section into a pool which is the best slide on Thimble. Extra bonus points!

Continue downstream a few hundred feet. Just ahead is the confluence with Straight Creek. The creek abruptly changes character becoming quite broad and full of rocks / fallen trees. Just before reaching the confluence, exit the creek DCL wherever is easiest and go right up the nose of a forested ridge. It's a little brushy but not that bad. Weave in and out through the trees staying right on the nose. You'll pass a nice view of the 100ft falls on Straight Creek. Keep going and bear slightly climber's left when the terrain flattens out. Pick up a user trail that leads you back to the campsite where you parked.

Red tape

None.

Beta sites

Video by Doug Hecker

Trip reports and media

Background

FD of Lower Thimble was on 8/14/17 featuring Haruka James Clay Lipscomb and Ryan Ernst.

Full full descent was made by Kevin Clark, Keith Campbell, Karl Helser, Lisa Ripps, and Wade Hewitt in Sept 2019.

Further Explorations

  • In 2018 we discovered a beautiful 100ft+ falls on Straight Creek just adjacent to the parking area that looks like it'd be a joy to rappel.
  • The creek flowing out of Blue Lake had more flow than upper Thimble in summer 2019. Highly likely there are one or more big falls on that tributary. This may be a better way to run Full Thimble...??
